partial Questions.Q: All these are characteristics of living things except
partial Questions.explanation: While movement, respiration, and nutrition are universal characteristics of living things, photosynthesis is specific to plants and some bacteria. Not all living organisms perform photosynthesis.

partial Questions.Q: Carbon, hydrogen ____, ____, ___ and ___ are the key building blocks of chemicals found in living things except
partial Questions.explanation: Carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, and phosphorus are indeed key building blocks of chemicals in living things. Helium, being an inert gas, is not typically found in biological molecules.

partial Questions.Q: ___ is the biology of body malfunction and disease
partial Questions.explanation: Pathology is the study of diseases and how they affect the body. It deals with the causes, processes, development, and consequences of diseases.

complete Questions.Q: ___ is the biology that determines how drugs and natural substances interact with the body
complete Questions.explanation: Pharmacology is the branch of biology that studies how drugs and other substances interact with living systems. It encompasses drug composition, properties, interactions, and effects on the body.

complete Questions.Q: ____ biologist works with ocean organisms
complete Questions.explanation: Marine biologists study organisms that live in saltwater environments, including oceans and seas. They focus on the biodiversity, behavior, and ecology of marine life.

complete Questions.Q: ___ biologist works with inland aquatic life
complete Questions.explanation: Freshwater biologists study organisms living in freshwater ecosystems such as lakes, rivers, and wetlands. They focus on the ecology, behavior, and conservation of freshwater species.

complete Questions.Q: The highest level of diversity of life on Earth is?
complete Questions.explanation: The biosphere represents the highest level of biological organization, encompassing all ecosystems on Earth. It includes all living organisms and their interactions with the environment across the entire planet.

complete Questions.Q: The movement of part of plant bodies in response to external stimuli is
complete Questions.explanation: Tropism refers to the growth or turning movement of a plant in response to an external stimulus. Common types include phototropism (response to light) and gravitropism (response to gravity).

complete Questions.Q: The process of animals moving themselves from one place to another is referred to as
complete Questions.explanation: Locomotion is the self-propelled movement of animals from one place to another. It can involve walking, swimming, flying, or other forms of movement.

complete Questions.Q: When green grass due to chlorophyll trap sunlight to produce food, it is known as ___ nutrition
complete Questions.explanation: Autotrophic nutrition refers to the process where organisms produce their own food using inorganic substances. In plants, this occurs through photosynthesis, where chlorophyll captures sunlight to convert CO2 and water into glucose.

complete Questions.Q: When animals or certain plants that lack chlorophyll depend on plants for food, it is known as ___ nutrition
complete Questions.explanation: Heterotrophic nutrition is the mode of nutrition where organisms obtain organic food molecules by consuming other organisms or their products. This includes animals and plants that lack chlorophyll, such as some parasitic plants.

complete Questions.Q: Detachment or formation of a new separate individual from a part of the mother organism is
complete Questions.explanation: Asexual reproduction involves the production of genetically identical offspring from a single parent. This includes processes like budding, fragmentation, and vegetative propagation in plants.

complete Questions.Q: The fusion of sex cells or gametes from two organisms is
complete Questions.explanation: Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of male and female gametes (sex cells) to form a zygote. This process combines genetic material from two parents, leading to genetic diversity in offspring.

complete Questions.Q: The population is made up of a group of individuals known as
complete Questions.explanation: A population consists of a group of organisms of the same species living in a particular area at a specific time.

complete Questions.Q: A biosphere is divided into smaller regions known as
complete Questions.explanation: The biosphere is divided into ecosystems, which are functional units consisting of living organisms interacting with each other and their non-living environment.

complete Questions.Q: Climates fit into several groups known as
complete Questions.explanation: Biomes are large-scale ecosystems characterized by similar climate, flora, and fauna. They represent distinct climate and vegetation types.

complete Questions.Q: Different communities define what specific traits must be available to allow an organism to mate and pass along the choice gene to the next generation which is the concept of ___ idea.
complete Questions.explanation: This concept refers to Darwin's theory of natural selection, where organisms with favorable traits are more likely to survive and reproduce, passing these traits to future generations.

complete Questions.Q: ___ is the smallest and most fundamental unit of matter.
complete Questions.explanation: An atom is the smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element. It is the fundamental building block of all matter.

complete Questions.Q: A ___ is a chemical structure consisting of at least two atoms held together by one or more chemical bonds.
complete Questions.explanation: A molecule is the smallest unit of a chemical compound that can take part in a chemical reaction. It consists of two or more atoms bonded together.

complete Questions.Q: An example of macromolecule is ____
complete Questions.explanation: DNA is a large, complex molecule that carries genetic information. It is an example of a macromolecule, which are very large molecules typically formed by polymerization of smaller subunits.

complete Questions.Q: Some cells contain aggregates of macromolecules surrounded by membranes; these are called ____.
complete Questions.explanation: Organelles are specialized structures within cells that perform specific functions. They are often enclosed by membranes and contain various macromolecules.

complete Questions.Q: ___ are single-celled or colonial organisms that do not have membrane-bound nuclei or organelles
complete Questions.explanation: Prokaryotes are simple, single-celled organisms that lack a membrane-bound nucleus and other membrane-enclosed organelles. Bacteria and Archaea are examples of prokaryotes.

complete Questions.Q: ___ do have membrane-bound organelles and a membrane-bound nucleus
complete Questions.explanation: Eukaryotes are organisms whose cells contain a nucleus and other organelles enclosed within membranes. This includes all plants, animals, fungi, and protists.

complete Questions.Q: In larger organisms, cells combine to make ___
complete Questions.explanation: Tissues are groups of similar cells that work together to perform a specific function. They are the next level of organization above cells in multicellular organisms.

complete Questions.Q: ___ are collections of tissues grouped together performing a common function.
complete Questions.explanation: Organs are structures composed of two or more different types of tissues that work together to perform specific functions within an organism.

complete Questions.Q: An ___ consists of all the living things in a particular area together with the abiotic, non-living parts of that environment
complete Questions.explanation: An ecosystem includes all living organisms in an area, along with the non-living components of their environment, interacting as a system.

complete Questions.Q: ___ is the collection of all ecosystems
complete Questions.explanation: The biosphere is the global sum of all ecosystems, integrating all living beings and their relationships, including their interaction with the elements of the lithosphere, hydrosphere, and atmosphere.

complete Questions.Q: The fundamental molecular components of all organisms are carbohydrates, nucleic acids, proteins and ___
complete Questions.explanation: Lipids, along with carbohydrates, nucleic acids, and proteins, are the four major classes of biological macromolecules that are essential for all known forms of life.

complete Questions.Q: ___ produce energy to power the cell while ___ enable green plants to utilize the energy in sunlight to make sugars.
complete Questions.explanation: Mitochondria are known as the powerhouses of the cell, producing energy through cellular respiration. Chloroplasts are found in plant cells and are responsible for photosynthesis, converting light energy into chemical energy.

complete Questions.Q: Human beings belong to the species known as
complete Questions.explanation: Homo sapiens is the scientific name for the human species. It is the only extant human species and is characterized by a highly developed brain and bipedal locomotion.

complete Questions.Q: ___ refers to the form and structures of organisms.
complete Questions.explanation: Morphology is the study of the form and structure of organisms. It includes aspects of the outward appearance (shape, structure, color, pattern) as well as the form and structure of the internal parts.

complete Questions.Q: The study of how disease and individual characteristics are affected by hereditary and demonstrate the point is known as
complete Questions.explanation: Genetics is the study of heredity and the variation of inherited characteristics. It examines how traits are passed from parents to offspring and how these traits express themselves.

complete Questions.Q: ___ involves organizing and categorizing the diversity of life based on shared characteristics and evolutionary relationships.
complete Questions.explanation: Taxonomy is the science of naming, describing, and classifying organisms into groups based on shared characteristics. It provides a standardized system for categorizing the diversity of life.

complete Questions.Q: The Linnaean system was developed by Carl Linnaeus in the
complete Questions.explanation: Carl Linnaeus, often called the Father of Taxonomy, developed his system of binomial nomenclature in the 18th century. This system is still the basis for modern biological classification.

complete Questions.Q: Who is regarded as one of the early founders of taxonomy
complete Questions.explanation: John Ray, an English naturalist, is considered one of the founders of modern taxonomy. He published important works on plants, animals, and natural theology, and his approach to classification was an important precursor to Linnaeus' system.

complete Questions.Q: ___, a Swedish botanist and physician is referred to as the 'Father of Taxonomy'.
complete Questions.explanation: Carl Linnaeus, also known as Carl von Linn√©, is widely regarded as the Father of Taxonomy. He formalized the modern system of naming organisms, known as binomial nomenclature.

complete Questions.Q: Who emphasized the importance of fossil studies and introduced the concept of catastrophism
complete Questions.explanation: Georges Cuvier, a French naturalist and zoologist, was a major figure in natural sciences research in the early 19th century. He is known for establishing the fields of paleontology and comparative anatomy.

complete Questions.Q: Whose work on the 'Origin of Species' in 1859 emphasized the importance of common ancestry
complete Questions.explanation: Charles Darwin's seminal work 'On the Origin of Species' published in 1859 introduced the scientific theory that populations evolve over generations through natural selection.

complete Questions.Q: Which German biologist coined the terms 'phylogeny' and 'ecology'.
complete Questions.explanation: Ernst Haeckel, a German zoologist, naturalist, and artist, is credited with coining many biological terms including 'phylogeny' and 'ecology'. He was a proponent of Darwinism in Germany.

complete Questions.Q: The three primary domains are the following except
complete Questions.explanation: The three-domain system, introduced by Carl Woese, divides cellular life forms into Archaea, Bacteria, and Eukarya. Animalia is a kingdom within the domain Eukarya.

complete Questions.Q: The second-highest level of standard hierarchy is
complete Questions.explanation: In the standard taxonomic hierarchy, Kingdom is the second-highest level, below Domain and above Phylum.

complete Questions.Q: A group of related species that share common characteristics is
complete Questions.explanation: A genus is a taxonomic rank used in biological classification that comes above species and below family. It consists of species which have similar characteristics.

complete Questions.Q: The most specific level of classification, representing a group of individuals that can interbreed and produce fertile offspring is
complete Questions.explanation: Species is the most specific level of classification in taxonomy. It represents a group of organisms that can interbreed and produce viable, fertile offspring under natural conditions.

complete Questions.Q: Humans are classified with which order?
complete Questions.explanation: Humans (Homo sapiens) are classified under the order Primates, which also includes apes, monkeys, lemurs, and lorises.

complete Questions.Q: ___ are the smallest independently functioning entities in living organisms.
